Halloween mascara-se de Brexit
01 Nov 2019, 11:43 by Euronews 



A 31 de outubro, a noite, que foi de Halloween, seria também a última antes do Brexit. A política acabou por mudar os planos, mas as alterações não atrapalharam a festa em Londres, onde a companhia de teatro Dot Dot Dot decidiu celebrar a data de forma peculiar.
A noite era um convite ao terror, uma passagem para a obscuridade que o Reino Unido, mais ou menos reticente, decidiu aceitar. Na véspera de todos os santos, diz a crença popular que os espíritos andam à solta e entre os vivos o ambiente pode tornar-se aterrador.
Na capital inglesa, houve quem tivesse decidido enfrentar o Brexit, vestindo a pele de quem quer vê-lo acontecer. De fato, peruca loira e bandeira do Reino Unido na mão, o ator Will Barton entra na sala e na personagem de Boris Johnson.
"Eles disseram que não íamos ganhar o referendo e estavam errados. Eles disseram que o parlamento não ia aprovar o meu acordo. Estavam errados. Eles disseram que não íamos concretizar o Brexit até 31 de outubro... e estavam certos. Bem, não estavam errados. Não estavam errados, mas havemos de lá chegar".
A saída do Reino Unido da União Europeia pode ter mudado de data, mas a festa estava marcada. Para já todos tiveram motivos para celebrar, afinal de contas, ainda não foi desta que o Brexit foi o fim do mundo
text:
Halloween masquerade from Brexit
01 Nov 2019, 11:43 by Euronews



On October 31, the night, which was Halloween, would also be the last before Brexit. The policy eventually changed plans, but the changes did not hinder the party in London, where the theater company Dot Dot Dot decided to celebrate the date in a peculiar way.
The night was an invitation to terror, a gateway to obscurity that the more or less reticent UK decided to accept. On the eve of all saints, it is popular belief that spirits are at large and among the living the environment can become terrifying.
In the English capital there were those who had decided to face Brexit, wearing the skin of those who want to see it happen. In fact, blonde wig and UK flag in hand, actor Will Barton enters the room and the character of Boris Johnson.
"They said we were not going to win the referendum and they were wrong. They said parliament would not approve my agreement. They were wrong. They said we were not going to run Brexit until October 31 ... and they were right. Well, no. they were wrong. They were not wrong, but we will get there. "
The departure of the United Kingdom from the European Union may have changed date, but the party was scheduled. For now everyone has had reason to celebrate, after all, this is not yet what Brexit was the end of the world
